text: [Music]
we I was in uh the in Gaza Strip with a
photographer some years ago uh while our
fat was still alive and we were trying
to talk our way into um being hosted by
the alaxa Martyr brigades which is a
militant group and it took a lot of
groundwork to sort of ingratiate
ourselves with them and um one one day
they showed up at our guest house in a
in a van um uh and put some hoods over
our heads and drove us around for about
an hour and at by the time we got to
their safe house it was pretty late at
night and they couldn't reveal their
identities to us so they were wearing
hoods and um when it came out that uh I
was American um the leader of this uh
little band of locks of Martyrs uh kind
of freaked out and got very angry and
started shouting at me and my young
translator was terrified and he was
having trouble uh even translating
clearly what the guy was saying and and
I was sat down in a chair and there were
a lot of very sort of big guys with
hoods with weapons sort of musling in on
me and uh and he was you know harping on
I could hear America America and I was
trying to find out from my translator
what he was saying and and and hoping to
break through and make a little uh you
know change the topic somehow and I
finally told him well I don't live in
America I was living in Spain at the
time and um mentioned tell I said tell
him I'm a supporter of Real Madrid the
soccer team and it sort of took him back
a little I could see his eyes through
the ski mask and he sort of stopped for
a second and uh and he said Zinedine
zidan Who was the player for Real Madrid
and Algerian and a Great Hero to the
people of of uh of that part of the
world and I said Zinedine zidan number
one zizu and and this guy suddenly his
demeanor completely changed and he uh he
shook my hand and ordered tea and some
of the guys put down their weapons and
went and got tea and we sat and we had
tea and the whole the whole sort of
atmosphere changed and eventually a ski
Mas too came off and um another guy came
up and wanted me to feel his leg where
the Israelis had had broken his
shinbone and uh and then wanted to tell
me he learned his English which was a
few words but had never left the Gaza
Strip I said how did you learn your
English he said
movies and uh then he asked me uh you
know if I wanted to know his favorite
movie uh he asked me in English I said
yes he said Being John
malovich and I said you where did you
get be being John malovich and now we're
through the translator and apparently
the copy of it was uh being sold in a
Bazaar in in Gaza City and and he loves
this film Being John malovich and it's
those weird moments of surprise that I
think uh are sort of the genuine stuff
that we're looking for as journalists
and often don't make it into the the
newspaper and get left in the files on
our computers and and don't actually get
read but it's those little um Sparks of
uh Humanity that are common you know the
things that uh you could relate to in
your living room in New York uh having
just watched the same movie as a as a
militant in Gaza and um I think those
are some of the things we look for
